title: Microstructural Evolution and Mechanical Behavior of an Additively Manufactured Pseudoelastic Shape Memory Alloy
content: Shape memory alloys (SMAs) display unique functional behavior caused by a reversible martensitic phase transformation [1]. This transformation behavior makes SMAs an important group of materials for applications ranging from aerospace, biomedical, and robotics [2,3]. Despite these attractive mechanical properties, SMAs are difficult to fabricate and machine with conventional processes, which limits their manufacturing to simple shapes [4]. Additive manufacturing (AM) offers an avenue for creating more complex, functional geometries as well as controlling SMA microstructure across multiple length scales [5].
